4. Identification: Biochemical tests and molecular techniques, such as sequencing of the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region of the ribosomal DNA, are commonly used to identify and differentiate C. auris from other Candida species.

5. Clinical significance: C. auris has emerged as an important human pathogen, causing invasive infections, particularly in healthcare settings. It has shown resistance to multiple antifungal drugs, making it a significant threat to public health.

Overall, Candidozyma auris is a medically relevant yeast species that has gained attention due to its ability to cause severe infections and its increasing resistance to commonly used antifungal therapies.
